[h1] Fallout 76 [/h1]

I started to play Fallout 76 during the Quarantine around 2021. When the game had the major content updates to improve the major issues of lacking stories, npcs and other things in the game. So i am reviweing the product from the perspective how the game feels since that. (I did not play since launch). 
At first when you make character you have option to start at lvl 1 or 20. Which i find super awesome, for those who knows Fallout games in it's core of gameplay then they can choose the higher lvl with starter build of cards. Yes cards, in F76 the progression system of your character let's say ,,build'' is summarized into more simple way of handling compare to F4 and F3. You still have perks, but you use perk cards with its description. Each card has different attributes or meaning what they do. For example Aqua Boy does literally allow you to swim everywhere without getting it's radiation from it's water. I find this very awesome, as F76 is live service online game, so i do not feel strssed much about it. The story feels quite alright, it's of course not the best Fallout story ever made, but i can say at least it's decent, and explain some small things to other games, because this game is described as ,,Prequel'' to Fallout games. Time to time there is small detail that explains some minor stuff, that happens let's say in Fallout 4 and vice versa. The combat is quite almost same as Fallout 4, except that V.A.T.S works a little differently, you can still highlight the parts of body and shoot, but you do not get the slowered time or action camera when you kill some enemy NPC. What i really like about F76 is the open world, and huuge sepration of ,,biomes'' each region is looking differently. For example there is more natural side of West Virginia like Forest, where i like to relax and explore every single time when i do not feel like for much of danger. Or Toxic Valley, as it's say in name, yes it is very Toxic with radiation and things are quite messy. The game as whole feels bit better everytime they do release Major Content Update every 3 months, this year we go for the first time ever ability to play as Ghoul and also Beth added side activity Fishing, which i mean i find welcoming, as sometimes i want relax and do something else than just killing stuff all the time. 
There ofc are negatives, such as classical clunky UI by Beth, animations sometimes glitch and it can be annoying during Public Events, sometimes i am stuck in the rock and need to relog. Also the balance of current builds might feel very frustrating specially for veterans, as they did nerf some stuff or over power some stuff, that does not make much of sense in Fallout logic, but hopefully they will balance it out with future updates. 
 

[b] Pros: [/b]
+ Vision of Fallout 76 to be friendly for solo players either multiplayer players either casual scene of players
+ Modding scene is active, i recommend to check out specially ,,Text Chat Mod'' very handy to have
+ Awesome soundtrack as every Fallout game always had
+ The niche of lore, weird humor, classy jokes of Fallout
+ Perk Card System for making Build of your character, very friendly for newcomers and vice versa
+ Combat is quite fun, specially in first person mode (my preference) 
+ Different type of ranged and melee weapons to choose from, some even has funny sound effects! 
+ Graphics are quite decent, but that is again about preference of each person, so it's difficult to recommend as positive or negative
+ Content Updates every 3 months with change of ,,Seasons'' which is kind of Battle Pass, the biggest expansion like updates occur usually every year of late November to early December
+ Replayability of game, in the meaning, it is fun to play with alts, to explore different builds or different choices in story lines
+ The bagame offers subscription, which is voluntary, i can't play without it as i am quite addictive hoarder so the unlimited scrap box is for me much needed, but you can survive without subscription there are many handy guides for hoarding organization so your stash box is not over consumed
 
[b] Cons: [/b]
- Optimization can be tricky to review, i would say, it definitely can use some rework major update to support modern hardware right from engine,  The Creation engine is known for being bit clunky
- Animations are quite clunky, but i find it charming, but some can find it ,,cheap'' or old 
- Some of locations could you rework or revamp with lighting or better textures compare to new places that has been added as of late 
- Wish the Character Creator has more hair options for woman characters specially, there are only so few 
- Atomic Shop furniture, clothes may feel bit over priced, always wait for discount
- Some balance issues with perk card builds of Characters 
- Clunkyness of glitches, sometimes i glitch into rock, and need to relog or restart game 
- For some reason the game can crash out of nowhere, not often, very rarely, but it happens 

[b] Result: [/b]
I am giving The Fallout 76 decent 8/10, while the story is not ground breaking Fallout story, it does still deliver answers for some things about it's core lore. The combat is quite fun, specially in first person, building your own camp is also fun after the last update of improving the Ui to be way more friendly, soundtrack is again stellar and the future of Fallout 76 seems to be very interesting with it's ideas from Developer's Blogs on their Youtube. Is it worth the full price? I would say no it's not, i would say wait for discount because there is also optional Subscription with benefits either Cash Shop called Atomic Shop with sometimes really nice decorations and customizations like clothes.

I have played Fallout 76 off-and-on since release.
Years of free updates have transformed this game from what it was back then.

Some highlights of the changes I've witnessed over the past 22 seasons:

• Devs listened to community feedback: they improved existing systems, reduced barriers to entry, and added loads of new content.
• It now takes significantly less time to gear a character for end-game content.
• There are now multiple methods to obtain desired modifiers on weapons and armor, making it easier and allowing players to min/max builds without so much grinding.
• The building system has been completely overhauled making it more user-friendly and addressing countless bugs.
• Perk cards have been tweaked and rebalanced to allow for a greater diversity of builds to be viable.
• Several unique factions were added, each with a complete story-line to explore.
• Season passes - allowing you to unlock subscriber rewards - are now purchasable using in-game premium currency.
• New characters are given the option to advance directly to level 20 on start and are given a generous kit, offering a quicker progression to end-game content. You can get to level 50 within a few hours of beginning your journey.
• Multiple new locations have been added, including an extension of the world map to the south.
• Multiple new end-game dungeons and bosses have been added. Compared to the original end-game, the amount of content is enormous.

At the current sale price of $10, Fallout 76 is definitely worth trying out if you enjoy the series and would like to explore the wasteland with your friends.

[h2]Adventuring[/h2]
I started Fallout pretty late with Fallout 4 and loved it, so stepping into Fallout 76 felt familiar right away. Waking up in a vault, walking outside and exploring a ruined world full of tapes, notes and small stories still hits perfectly. I’m around 110 hours in now and still feel like jumping back in.

[h2]World and gameplay[/h2]
The game looks great and the shooting feels good, just like Fallout 4. Every location feels like it has something going on, and if you actually stop to listen to holotapes or read notes, you’ll find surprisingly good side stories. With all the updates since launch, there’s now a main story with the Overseer, human NPCs, new areas and a ton of quests.

[h2]Building, events and co-op[/h2]
Building with the C.A.M.P. system is one of the best parts of the game. You can create some really creative bases and even run a player shop. Public events keep the world active too, like Radiation Rumble or Scorched Earth. The community is friendlier than you’d expect, people drop gear or help out all the time. Co-op works well but you can solo most things if you feel like it.

[h2]Progression and endgame[/h2]
There’s a lot to work toward with perks, mutations, legendary gear and builds. Endgame has nukes, Daily Ops, expeditions and seasonal rewards, so there’s always something to chase. Nuking areas to spawn tougher enemies is still one of the coolest features in the game and changes the map in a big way.

[h2]Final thoughts[/h2]
Fallout 76 had a rough launch, but today it’s a completely different game. If you enjoy exploring, looting, building and slowly rebuilding a wasteland, it delivers exactly that. I’m taking a break for now, but I know I’ll return soon.

The game has vastly improved from the release I bore witness to from years back. The gunplay feels good (much like Fallout) and the game loop is good enough. Looting is fun and the stealth is braindead which works for me, I guess. I never expected the experience to be great and it never reached that point anyway, but what I didn't expect was a passable game at all considering what happened on launch for the world to see.

The key points that ruin this game now is the multitude of factors that snap me out of the "immersion" that companies love to tout. I can list it as points just to keep it short:

- Inventory and storage system detract from the whole looting and shooting experience, eventually either robbing you of all your playtime in the effort to manage or make you constantly make critical decisions on what should be an inconsequential aspect of the game.

- Enemies are stupid. Stats are used to compensate for this. Skill has almost no involvement in PvE fights as you either curbstomp everything in sight or get slapped back to last Tuesday on the drop of a dime. Not the most fun experience.

- A playerbase that's seemingly so bored of the game that they go completely out of their game to find ways to kill you and really, really make the highest effort to ruin your day, even if it means hounding you for hours. It's hard to trust any player that coaxes you in a certain direction, expecially since communication is dumbed down to a spam of generic emotes...

- A very poorly written story. This wouldn't be so bad if the choices had any major impact on the gameplay. In fact, call this a hot take but actual consequences in the decisions for a game you can't savescum sounds like a nice change of pace. Instead we have all choices leading down a golden road covered in horseshit that the writers used to pad out a lot of the story with. Really, some of the plot points are mind-numbing even when you don't think about what you're reading or hearing.

- Lag. Mf'ing lag. Ever fought a skyrim dragon with 3000ms ping that kicks in when more than 5 players go rambo in one location? This is the game. Never expected to see a turn-based raid in a FPS MMO.

That's about the gist of what I want to complain about. Get the game when the price drops down by 75% or something. It ain't good enough for its regular price tag but you can definitely find some good time wasted with this game on sale.

Fallout 4 is one of my all time favourite games - by comparison Fallout 76 is just terrible, but I can set that aside, no problem. Comparing it to one of my favourite games is a very high bar.

However, FO76, which will be celebrating its 8th birthday next time, has the dubious honour of being the buggiest, most screen-freezing and crash-prone game I have ever played BY FAR.

It's worth noting, that according to my maths, a subscription to FO76 is horrifically poor value for money compared to any game I have ever played. Personally, I refuse to buy it, which is something I normally always do for the games I play, because I feel like it would be giving Bethesda permission to wee up and down my back.


The bugs:
You'll experience them most, if not every gaming session, regardless of length.

For instance, I have 5 characters and 500+ hours in-game. Yet, none of them have ever successfully delivered a quest to one of the daily questgivers, Chloe in the Mire, because no matter what I have tried, it's impossible to talk to her, but receiving the quest has only been a problem on one of my characters.

Other frequent issues include: unlootable corpses, invisible enemies or enemies stuck under ground or inside objects, and the like. That will often block quest progression, and if it happens in an instance you'll have to start over, same goes when the game crashes in an instance, which can be very time consuming.

C.A.M.P. objects, including ones you have bought, disappearing, and a whole array of visual bugs, that makes FO76 seem like the game was designed by a guy in his basement, and he was in a hurry.

Most weapon types have multiple bugs, however those often change, since Bethesda are constantly screwing up, I mean 'balancing', the weapons.

Another bug is when you're just walking, and you randomly die. No hostiles, no nothing, you just die for no reason whatsoever.
That's particularly fun when you're on your way to a new area, where you have no fast travel points, so you have to go back to find your stuff from halfway across the map.

Personally, I think one of the worst ones, is when your weapon breaks every time you attempt to store it, equip it or fire it.
If you don't have a stash of mods (500+ hours and I'm not even close to having that), it feels near game breaking because the only good weapon you have or just the weapon you really like. The weapon you have basically built your character around is now lost forever. This has happened to 3 of my characters, a total of 5 times. I now keep a back-up as similar to my main weapon as possible for on all my characters for the next time it happens - I read about this bug after the first time in a 6 year old reddit thread(!).

Sadly, I could go on, but I think I have made my point.

The crashes:
When I started playing Fallout 76, I spent 2-3 hours checking my specs, my internet connection, and testing other games, because I couldn't understand why it was constantly freezing/crashing or disconnected from the server. I couldn't find a fault except with the game, because, of course, it turned out to be another well-known, years old, issue.

I got so annoyed with it though, that I actually did the maths on it (cause I'm that kind of nerd) over a 4 day period of heavy gaming:
Fallout 76 crashed, on average, every 2 hours, 18 minutes and 51 seconds during that period, and there is nothing that suggests that it has changed for the better since. The good news is that if your gaming session are usually short, you shouldn't experience that many crashes...


I'm not even going to waste my breath with Bethesda's inability to roll out any update without screwing up the entire game for a few days.

I'm still here though. I'm still playing it, because there are good aspects of the game, although I'm struggling to find any that could make up for all these issues.
However, I can't imagine that I would be wasting my valuable spare time with this game, if I hadn't been gotten bored with my other games and wasn't stuck at home with a broken foot.

I certainly wouldn't pay 25% more than a subscription to WoW every month to receive next to nothing except a few cosmetics and storage space, and frankly WoW is a much better and of course stable game.

I would love to have access to private worlds, so I could trade between my characters, but that's an incredibly low bar for a subscription. Something that, for instance, is free and easily done in WoW and other games. Bethesda has just gone the greedy route, and charges you a lot of money for things that should have been a free part of the game.

There are truly no words strong enough to capture what I see as Bethesda’s abysmal fall from grace—and that hits especially hard because Fallout is my favorite IP of all time. More than Lord of the Rings, Game of Thrones, Harry Potter, Call of Duty, Resident Evil, or Battlefield. Nothing comes close. Fallout shaped my taste, my imagination, and what I expect from an RPG.

Which makes the studio’s decline feel personal.

Bethesda’s golden age was undeniable:
• Oblivion (2006)
• Fallout 3 (2008)
• New Vegas (2010) — more on this later
• Skyrim (2011)

That era was legendary. Those games were ambitious, strange, soulful, and they meant something. They were cultural events.

And then something happened.

By “something,” I mean what felt like Bethesda flipping the switch into online-service, monetization-heavy, creatively hollow “slop mode.” The spark vanished. The identity faded. The corporate design philosophy took over.

Fallout 4 (2015) was the first major warning sign. Beautiful to look at, fun moment-to-moment, but the role-playing depth had been gutted. Settlements overshadowed story. Choices felt shallow. The soul wasn’t there.

Then came Fallout 76 (2018), which to me was the moment the decline stopped being subtle. Instead of building on what made Fallout great, Bethesda pivoted hard into live-service systems—battle-pass-style progression, cosmetic shops, and engagement-loop design. It felt like a Fortnite-flavored Fallout, without the heart or identity that defined the series.

And before anyone says, “But Obsidian had Fallout 3 basically done—Bethesda did all the work!” let’s remember something:
Obsidian had 18 months and reused Bethesda’s assets to make New Vegas—and ended up creating one of the most beloved, richly written Fallout games ever made.

Fast-forward to 2015–2018. Bethesda had Fallout 4’s full asset suite, the same head start Obsidian had—plus three years of development. And what we got was, in my view, a sloppily executed, aggressively monetized live-service experiment wearing a Fallout skin.

Alright, look here. Look, listen. This game is both good and bad. You can't expect a masterpiece or even a very memorable experience, but it is a fun experience. If that's enough for you, then get this game. I played this game almost every day with my brother back in 2020-2023 on the PS5. I have over 600 hours on this game over there. I bought Fallout First all those years, though one of those was because I forgot to cancel the auto-renewal. Still, I enjoyed playing this game and completing the battle pass every season. There's plenty of content in this game now after all the updates to keep you engaged for as long as I was.

Here's probably something more important for most people: why I stopped playing Fallout 76 for a while. I believe the only reason I was able to play this game every day without getting tired was because of Fallout First. Like Elder Scrolls Online, the subscription gives you an unlimited stash amount that is required for long term enjoyment. Even though I didn't craft so many things to the point I needed all that space, it just cuts out a significant amount of frustration. There's already too much micromanagement and menuing in this game that I hate. Adding more by requiring me to stop playing and drop all my junk items and ammo so I can sprint again is astronomically stupid. I already spent more on this game than any other game I've ever played by paying for Fallout First for 3 years. That's $300 + $40 (PC version a few weeks after launch) + $10 (Xbox version a year after launch) = $350. I never buy microtransactions or subscriptions for any games. I play 100s of hours of Call of Duty and progress the battle pass, all without paying a dime. I can ignore $50 skins and $20 battle passes that only give emblems and calling cards with a couple double XP tokens mixed in. I don't excuse any of that nonsense, but I can enjoy the game with it. This game is an exception for me, and all the money I've paid isn't enough for them (the developers / publishers). I truly can't enjoy this game without Fallout First. I love scavenging and collecting things in the open world. Dropping them all the time makes it feel like a waste, and there's not enough storage space for non payers. The more I talk about the game's bad business practices, the less I want to recommend it, so I'll stop here. Just know that I could go on. I could go on and on and on...
